data.title: The food is quickly  made and served hot.
data.text: I eat here many Saturday afternoons throughout the year.  The menu is varied though I generally stick to the soups which are always very tasty served hot with the cold ingredients on the side that the customer can add as they wish.  The soup bowl is large and not expensive either 9 or 10 dollars.

data.title: poor attitude
data.text: people walk away becsuse employees are indifferent to providing service. Closing time is supposedly 7pm on many nights but the staff turn their backs and pretendf theyre clised while other eateries at 5th St Market are open and thriving.

data.title: Salty Wings
data.text: Ordered the wings appetizers and and my daughter and I found them to be extremely salty.When I told the man behind the counter he said they had changed the sauce ,and that was why they were salty.He never offered me another dish or even my money back.He really didn't seem interested in my concern.After stewing a bit I went back to have him taste it .He did and  stated it tasted ok.He still didn't offer a substitute dish or a refund and still seemed indifferent to my complaint.I then told him I didn't like his attitude and that he should have offered some type of compensation.He did offer and I told him it was too late and I would not dine here again.I went back to our seat and completed my lunch with my daughter and friends.Just as we were about to leave the owner of the restaurant came by our table.She stated that she had heard the conversation between me and her worker.She stated that he was wrong and and credited my credit card the price of the wings.She was a very nice young lady and I did appreciate her coming by and expressing her concern for the way I was treated by her employee and the quality of the food.Despite this I will not go back here eat.

data.title: Not all is good
data.text: Three of us ate at the Ocha Asian Kitchen last Saturday around 5 pm.  Of the three dishes - soup and wraps were a three, fried calamari was a two, and the chicken wings were dreadful.   The staff could be viewed from the open kitchen and they were slow and seemed unsure of how to prepare the dishes we ordered.  During the cooking process, an unpleasant odor of old and rancid cooking oil was wafting its way from the stove.  After my wife and I concurred that the chicken wings were unfit to be eaten as they were hard, tough and had a weird burnt off flavor, I returned the mostly uneaten dish to the cook.  My complaint was met with indifference and incomprehension. We ate here in September and earlier in the afternoon and had good food and service from a different staff.  Perhaps it was the time of day, or the owner or manager not being present that left us prey to a young and poorly trained staff. Also, we were the only ones eating from there - not a good sign.  This is just one of several eating places in this quaint and visually appealing food court in the Fifth St Public Market which is worth the trip.

data.title: Mouthwatering good!
data.text:
This was our first trip ever to Eugene, and we arrived hungry after a long trip from Bellevue, WA. Our hotel reservation was secure so we elected to drive downtown and find a place to eat. After walking for a bit and not finding something appealing, a lady who thought we looked lost asked us if we needed help. She then suggested this place inside a foodcourt. The place looked clean and the menu offered an interesting variety. We ordered the Thai Papaya Salad w medium spice, Barbecued chicken w/ rice, and Barbecued Babyback Ribs. The counter service was very friendly and courteous. The food that was cooked was even better. The salad was crunchy fresh, thai spicy and EXTRA yummy (I love papaya salad and know a bad one). My wife loved the chicken and said it was very moist inside, steaming hot and tatsy. My ribs were meaty, very substantial in quantity and the taste was a register ringing 10.
How we ended up there was purely by chance, but I would come back again in a heartbeat.
